definition.primary: A non-atherosclerotic, segmental, inflammatory vasculitis affecting small and medium-sized arteries and veins of the upper and lower extremities, almost exclusively associated with tobacco use, characterized by distal ischemia, superficial thrombophlebitis, and Raynaud phenomenon.
key_concepts: Strongly associated with tobacco/cannabis use - cessation essential for treatment
Affects young patients (typically < 45 years) without atherosclerotic risk factors
Involves both arteries and veins (distinguishing feature)
Segmental, non-atherosclerotic occlusion with corkscrew collaterals

demographics.gender: Historically male predominant (10:1), but female incidence increasing with smoking
demographics.geography: Higher in Asia, Middle East, Eastern Europe

association_with_tobacco.prevalence: Nearly 100% of patients are current or recent tobacco users
association_with_tobacco.dose_response: More severe disease with heavier tobacco use

mechanism.proposed: Immunologically mediated reaction to tobacco antigens in genetically susceptible individuals
inflammatory_phase: Highly cellular thrombus with polymorphonuclear cells
Intact internal elastic lamina (distinguishes from atherosclerosis)

vessels_affected: Small and medium arteries (tibial, radial, ulnar, digital)
Spares large arteries (femoral, brachial usually normal)

arterial_manifestations.description: Finger or toe ischemia with rest pain, ulceration, gangrene

phases_of_disease: Active phase: New ischemia, active inflammation
Quiescent phase: Stable disease with tobacco cessation
Recurrent phase: Flare with tobacco re-exposure

diagnostic_features: Distal extremity ischemia (claudication, rest pain, ulcers, gangrene)
Exclusion of atherosclerosis, diabetes, embolic sources

diagnostic_workup.findings: Normal inflammatory markers (ESR, CRP), negative autoimmune workup

tobacco_cessation.importance: Absolutely essential - disease progression virtually ceases with cessation
tobacco_cessation.all_forms: Must stop cigarettes, cigars, pipes, smokeless tobacco, cannabis

variable_benefit.evidence: RCT showing improved ulcer healing, pain relief
Limited data in Buerger disease specifically

revascularization.feasibility: Limited by distal disease and small vessel involvement
revascularization.outcome: Poor patency rates in those who continue smoking

sympathectomy.role: May improve rest pain, promote wound healing

amputation.indication: Refractory rest pain, non-healing ulcers, infection, gangrene
amputation.level: Often digital or transmetatarsal if possible

prognosis.mortality: Not directly fatal, but associated with increased cardiovascular mortality

learning_objectives: Recognize clinical features suggesting Buerger disease
Apply diagnostic criteria to differentiate from atherosclerotic PAD
Understand the critical importance of tobacco cessation
Select appropriate medical and surgical management
key_points: Tobacco cessation is the only proven treatment to halt disease progression
Affects young patients without traditional atherosclerotic risk factors
Involves both arteries and veins (migratory thrombophlebitis)
Corkscrew collaterals on arteriography are pathognomonic
Prognosis is excellent with smoking cessation, poor without
clinical_pearls: Think of Buerger disease in a young smoker with digital ischemia and normal proximal pulses
Ask about cannabis use - also implicated in disease pathogenesis
Superficial thrombophlebitis in young smoker is red flag

references.evidence_basis: Clinical series, RCTs for iloprost, observational studies
